Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: TelePathy: Telecommunication Systems Modeling and Engineering of Cell Communication Pathways

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER project, funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology program, will lead to the development of tools that will allow researchers to manipulate the behavior or state of cells, mostly microbes,for specific purposes or applications. The investigators will characterize and simulate the functions and dynamics of cell-communication networks using telecommunications and computer networks theory, and engineering principles. This fundamentally important research, if successful, will provide a novel perspective of how cells communicate, and will enable the simulation and the design of networks through cell behavior modification to perform useful functions such as the manufacture of chemicals, distributed environmental bio-sensing, and the control of cell proliferation and harmful states. This strongly interdisciplinary effort will offer valuable training for students and postdoctoral associates at all levels. The principle investigator will develop a course together with social scientists and ethicist to address how this work, and synthetic biology in general, will affect society as whole. The investigators will also mentor a team of undergraduates to participate in the International Genetically Engineered Machine competition.

The development of tools to analyze, model, and exploit cell-communication systems remains an unexplored avenue for both synthetic biology and computer network engineering. The goal of this project is to develop quantitative models based on telecommunications engineering principles, and by applying telecommunications metrics, to define and manipulate the exchange of information among cells. This will be achieved by pursuing four objectives: (1) the development of a modeling framework that will allow the identification of cell-communication pathways, and their chemical and physical parameters, from public databases; (2) the telecommunications metrics characterization of these cell-communication pathways, in particular focusing on currently poorly characterized syntrophic microbial systems; (3) the development of a computer simulation framework based on the COMSOL Multiphysics software platform to enable the validation of the developed models, and allow their further characterizations in a controlled in-silico environment; (4) the design and optimization of an artificial cell-communication system based on the syntrophy between two human gut microbes, i.e., Methanobrevibacter smithii and Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron, which will be a proof-of-concept of using the developed models to develop biological cell-communication systems able to reliably exchange artificial messages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall aim of the TelePathy (Telecommunication Systems Modeling and Engineering of Cell Communication Pathways) project was to explore the application of molecular communication systems engineering to the quantitative modeling of information exchange among biological cells, i.e., cell communication pathways, and the design of techniques to artificially control these pathways and the exchanged information through synthetic biology tools. An additional aim of this project was to educate the next generation of computer engineers and life science scientists in communication systems engineering applied to synthetic biology, through the creation of novel courses and their involvement into active research projects. 

These aims have been accomplished through the following Intellectual Merit Outcomes: i) We have abstracted, modeled, and characterized the communication system underlying the impact that environmental information has on a cell and its metabolism, based on the cell’s genetic code. ii) We have modeled, characterized, and redesigned a specific type of chained biochemical reactions in cell communications, namely, phosphorylation cascades, as signal filters in cell-to-cell communication systems. iii) We have designed, modeled, and characterized a complete communication system based on biological circuits in genetically engineered cells by stemming from techniques for information coding, and inspired by recent studies favoring the efficiency of analog computation over digital in biological cells. This is the very first time a communication-engineering-based design is applied to synthetic biology, opening novel perspectives for communications and networking research. iv) We have proposed a communication paradigm where digital information is propagated through the neurons in the nervous system, minimally interfering with the natural signal propagation, which addresses the main challenges in the design of Body-Area Networks (BANs). We have proposed two techniques, one based on haptic stimulation of nervous system’s pathways, and another based on the subthreshold stimulation of neurons. v) We have provided a mapping between the signal transport in endocrine (through the bloodstream) cell communication and the model of a telecommunication channel, thus enabling the application of telecom-based characterization tools to analyze and optimize the way information is propagated in the cardiovascular system. vi) We have designed components to aid cell-to-cell communication design and testing by stemming from molecular communication theory applied to microfluidic chips. While this is not the first-time microfluidics is utilized in molecular communication research, our tool is the first to reproduce the behavior of a biological circuit for communication as it would be in an engineered cell, without the need of a biology lab. vii) We have proposed a new paradigm in communications and networking research, namely, Internet of Bio-Nano Things (IoBNT), which is having a great impact in our community with more than 100 citations in less than 3 years from its publication. viii) We developed a joint model-based and experimental study of the bacterium B. theta and archeon M. smithii that sheds light on the mutualistic interactions between the two organisms, which are currently only postulated. These outcomes resulted in: 12 Published Conference Papers [venues: IEEE International Conference on Computer Communications (INFOCOM), ACM International Conference on Nanoscale Computing and Communication (NanoCom), IEEE Global Communications Conference (GLOBECOM), IEEE International Workshop on Signal Processing Advances in Wireless Communications (SPAWC), IEEE International Conference on Communications (ICC), ), Conference of IEEE in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC), IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing (ICASSP), International Workshop on Software Engineering for Science (SE4Science), International Workshop on Assurance Cases for Software-Intensive Systems (ASSURE), SPIE International Conference on Defense + Security (DCS)], 3 Published Journal Papers [venues: IEEE Communication Magazine, IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering, IEEE/ACM Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics], 2 Best Paper Awards [IEEE INFOCOM 2017 Best Paper Runner-up Award, ACM NanoCom Best Paper Award 2017], a Conference Presentation Award [IEEE INFOCOM 2017 Best In-session Presentation Award], and 14 Invited Talks.

The TelePathy project resulted in the following Broader Impact Outcomes: i) We created a brand-new course “Genetically Engineered Systems “, offered at the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, for both undergraduate and graduate students. ii) We organized and mentored the very first and second international Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) team in Nebraska (UNebraska-Lincoln team), which received a Silver Medal at the iGEM Jamboree 2016. iii) 5 graduate students prepared and defended their Master degree theses through this project [one is the recipient of the 2016-2017 UNL CSE Outstanding Master's Thesis Award]. iv) We mentored through this project a total of 8 graduate students and 2 undergraduate students. v) One REU-supported undergraduate student applied and received the McNair scholarship to continue pursuing his research path. vi) We participated to outreach activities with middle-high school students within the Future Problem Solving Program International (FPSPI), and with the Nebraska State Museum.
